objtitle.title: Head of a Man and Small Head of Ugolino

objdescid.compdate: c. 1780-85The small head of Ugolino at the bottom margin is related to the pencil sketch on the recto of the leaf, *Ugolino in Prison*, and is probably of about the same date. The large head recalls Blake's Visionary Heads of c. 1819 and later, but has also been dated to c. 1780-85 in Butlin 207 verso.

provenance.name: Victoria and Albert Museum
provenance.note: Inherited by Blake's wife Catherine at his death in 1827; acquired by Frederick Tatham, probably at Catherine Blake's death in 1831; sold Sotheby's, 29 April 1862, possibly lot 200 or 201 with 33 other works (2s. or 3s. to the dealer Francis Harvey) or lot 160 with four other works (9s. to George A. Smith); Smith by 1876, sold Christie's, 10 July 1880, in lot 121 or 122 (each lot bought by the dealer E. Parsons for 3s.); sold by Parsons to the Victoria and Albert Museum in 1881.

desc.objtitle: *Head of a Man and Small Head of Ugolino*, object 1 (Butlin 207 verso)

objnote.p: See also the pencil sketch on the recto of this leaf, *Ugolino in Prison*, and the Editors' Notes on that drawing. The small head at the bottom of this verso drawing is described by Butlin 207 as "crudely copied" from the head of Ugolino in the recto drawing; Butlin further states that this small head "may not be by Blake." This verso head, however, shows many differences from the head of Ugolino on the recto and may be an alternative version of that head, if indeed related to Ugolino. We believe that this small head is probably Blake's work.

illustration.illusobjdesc: A large head depicted from the neck up occupies the majority of the compositional space. The figure, who is male, has short and somewhat curly hair. He faces forward and right with eyes raised. At the center of the lower margin, a second forward-facing male figure, who is smaller and less detailed than the above head, is shown from the shoulders up. He has short hair and a beard; his mouth may be open. This small head may be an alternative version of Ugolino's head in the drawing on the recto.

component.illusobjdesc: A large head depicted from the neck up occupies the majority of the compositional space. The figure, who is male, has short and somewhat curly hair. He faces forward and right with eyes raised.

At the center of the lower margin, a second forward-facing male figure, who is smaller and less detailed than the above head, is shown from the shoulders up. He has short hair and a beard; his mouth may be open. This figure may be an alternative version of the head of Ugolino in the pencil drawing on the recto of this leaf, *Ugolino in Prison*.
